title: How many books are there in the Old Testament? - Quora

response.answer_text: The “Catholic Bible” consists a total of 46 books in the Old Testament whereas a “Protestant Bible” consists of a total of 39 books in the Old Testament. “CATHOLIC BIBLE DIFFERENT FROM OTHER CHRISTIAN BIBLES” Catholic Bibles differ in the number and order of books from those typically found in bibles used by Protestants. Catholic Bibles remained unchanged following the Reformation and so retained “seven books” that were “rejected principally” by Martin Luther King. Its canon of Old Testament texts is somewhat larger than that in translations used by the Protestants, which are typically based exclusively on the shorter Hebrew and Aramaic Masoretic Text. On the other hand, its canon, which does not accept all the books that are included in the Septuagint, is shorter than that of some churches of Eastern and Oriental Orthodoxy, which recognize other books as sacred scripture. “BOOKS IN THE CATHOLIC BIBLE” OLD TESTAMENT = 46 BOOKS GenesisExodusLeviticusNumbersDeuteronomyJoshuaJudgesRuth1 Samuel2 Samuel1 Kings2 Kings1 Chronicles2 ChroniclesEzraNehemiahTobit**Judith**Esther1 Maccabees**2 Maccabees**JobPsalmsProverbsEcclesiastesSong of SongsWisdom**Sirach**IsaiahJeremiahLamentationsBaruch**EzekielDanielHoseaJoelAmosObadiahJonahMicahNahumHabakkukZephaniahHaggaiZechariahMalachi** Seven (7) books in the Catholic Bible that are not found in the Protestant Bible “BOOKS IN THE PROTESTANT BIBLE” OLD TESTAMENT = 39 BOOKS GenesisExodusLeviticusNumbersDeuteronomyJoshuaJudgesRuth1 Samuel2 Samuel1 Kings2 Kings1 Chronicles2 ChroniclesEzraNehemiahEstherJobPsalmsProverbsEcclesiastesSong of SongsIsaiahJeremiahLamentationsEzekielDanielHoseaJoelAmosObadiahJonahMicahNahumHabakkukZephaniahHaggaiZechariahMalachi

Both Catholics and Protestants attest to the same 39 books of the Old Testament and 27 books of the New Testament. While Catholics and Orthodox do have additional books and include them in the same binding as the 66 canonized sacred texts, knowledgable Catholics and Orthodox do not hold these additional books to be equal to the canonized Scriptures. But they do give them considerable weight in developing doctrine. Because they were never included in the Old Testament by the Jews nor were they included in the earliest canon, Protestants may read these books as commentary but take the content “with a grain of salt” and certainly do not hold to them as having any divine authority. The treatment of the content of these books, the acceptance of church tradition instead of Scripture only (the Protestant position), and the acceptance of a pope are probably the sources of the great division between Catholics and Protestants.
